text: I don't trust "common wisdom" too much on this one. Ten years ago, if you asked about how long an interview for the radio should be, you would probably get similar to "ten minutes tops, except if you want to appeal to boomers", but then podcasts like Joe Rogan started making 3 hour long interviews that got insanely popular among youngsters.

text: Personally I feel like if I’m really interested, then long is good bc there’s a lot there and I’ll save it and come back etc. But if I’m just curious about the subject but not super interested, then short/medium is good because I can read it before I run out of attention span and feel that I came away with something. Whereas if it’s long, I’ll kinda skim and not really get where it was going. So maybe it depends on what audience you’re aiming at, the really interested folks, or passers-by.

text: depending on your goals, it doesn’t have to be a very thorough summary. just a question of what you want a time-starved reader to walk away with. and the more tantalizing you make the short lead, the more likely it will be that a time-starved reader would schedule time to read the whole thing
